Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 6]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Greetings, fellow players. As the medic, I chose not to heal in the first round due to a lack of information. With player 5\'s unfortunate demise, I encourage everyone to share observations that may help us identify potential threats and protect key players moving forward. I commit to using my healing ability strategically as more information comes to light. Let\'s work together to uncover the truth and emerge victorious.\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Player 4 has made a bold and potentially risky move by revealing their role as the medic this early on, which either showcases their commitment to helping the village or acts as a deception. Caution is advised. While I am not accusing anyone, Player 2\'s silence could potentially be a tactic to avoid detection, warranting discussion and participation from them. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. It\'s risky to claim such a role without evidence but it could also be part of a larger strategy to draw out the werewolves. Regarding Player 6, I believe we should not hastily cast suspicion upon them simply because they\'ve pointed out the potential silence tactic of Player 2. Instead, we should encourage all to speak and put forth information that can be useful. We have yet to hear from Player 3, and I suggest we give them the chance to share their perspective. We need to act with unity and thoughtful consideration before making any drastic decisions."\n\nWhat could happen? theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Statement and Protect Player 6\nSummary: "My fellow villagers, I\'ve been observing the discussion carefully. It is distressing to lose a member of our community so early. As for Player 4 revealing themselves as the medic, it\'s a brave move that could either be true or a strategy. It\'s risky to claim such a role without evidence but it could also be part of a larger strategy to draw out the werewolves. Regarding Player 6, I believe we should not hastily cast suspicion upon them simply because they\'ve pointed out the potential silence tactic of Player 2. Instead, we should encourage all to speak and put forth information that can be useful. We have yet to hear from Player 3, and I suggest we give them the chance to share their perspective. We need to act with unity and thoughtful consideration before making any drastic decisions.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players may react to my statements with some caution. Since I am providing a protective stance towards Player 6, who has not yet been under heavy suspicion but has been noticed for their comment on Player 4\'s reveal as medic, my support might project the image that I am a logical and calm-minded player, appealing to collective reasoning.\n\nPlayers might appreciate my call to encourage Player 3 to speak, as it shows I am interested in hearing from everyone, which is behavior expected from a concerned villager. However, the players are also trying to find relationships between each other\'s statements, and some may find it odd that I chose to defend Player 6\'s stance instead of contributing new information or raising suspicion elsewhere.\n\nPlayer 4 might become slightly more suspicious of both Player 6 and me due to the defense I offered, but without substantial evidence, they cannot act solely on intuition. Meanwhile, Player 2 may feel pressure to speak up after Player 6\'s and my comments on their silence which could reveal more about their role or thoughts.\n\nIntuition and deduction play significant roles here. Astute players might start to wonder if there is a connection between Player 6 and me, but without evidence, these thoughts may not immediately lead to action. If Player 6 and I can continue to shift the focus onto other players and maintain the narrative that we are constructive participants, we could avoid direct suspicion for now. \n\nThe current medic claim might draw the attention of the werewolves in the next night phase, where Player 4 may become a target to sow further confusion and sever potential village strategies. Assuming Player 4 truly is the medic, their early reveal might cost them their life unless they manage to successfully shield themselves.\n\nThe next day phase may involve more in-depth analysis of the behavior of Player 3, who is yet untalked up to this point, and additional contributions from Player 2 could create new dynamics and suspicions. Depending on how the night phase goes, the village\'s focus may shift based on who is attacked next.\n\nOverall, the villagers might still be wrestling with uncertainty without concrete evidence, and the night\'s events will significantly shape the suspicions and strategies for the following days.\nCase 2: Deceptive Challenge and Deceptive Statement\nSummary: "As night fell on our village, it was truly unfortunate to find Player 5 taken from us. With the dire situation we face, clarity and strategic actions are required. It seems to me that while Player 4\'s early claim to be the medic could be an effort to aid the village, it could also be a ploy to undermine us from within, and Player 6 was quick to divert attention from this possibility by highlighting Player 2\'s silence. I find this inherently suspicious and think we should probe further into their motivations. Are they working in tandem to distract us from a greater threat? Moreover, I urge Player 3 to come forward and speak, as their silence could be indicative of a strategy to remain unnoticed. Let us not be swayed by mere conjecture but rather by careful investigation and reasoned debate.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it\'s likely that some suspicions may shift towards Player 4 and Player 6. Player 4\'s early reveal as the medic might be questioned by others due to the seed of doubt I\'ve planted, and attention might be redirected towards assessing Player 4\'s motivations and truthfulness. Meanwhile, Player 6, already seen diverting attention towards Player 2, may come under scrutiny for possibly trying to defend Player 4 or creating a distraction, as per my suggestion that their actions could be part of a coordinated effort.\n\nThe villagers could view my interjection as an attempt to participate actively in the hunt for werewolves, seeing me as engaged and potentially trustworthy due to challenging others rather than defending. However, if I am too forceful or if my reasoning seems flawed, it could backfire and result in some players becoming suspicious of my motives.\n\nPlayer 3, who I urged to speak, might feel pressured to contribute or may become defensive. How they respond could either alleviate or heighten suspicion upon them.\n\nIn terms of the potential impact on the larger game:\n- If my deceptive strategy works, it can buy time for the werewolves by scattering the villagers\' focus. This could lead to more rounds where we are able to evade detection and eliminate villagers at night.\n- If villagers start doubting Player 4 and Player 6, this disruption could lead to incorrect lynching during the day, which benefits the werewolves.\n- Should players start suspecting that the uncertainty sewn is deliberate and orchestrated, they may begin to consider that I am too keen on pushing accusations without solid proof, which might draw unwanted attention to me in the longer-term.\n- Particularly analytical players might notice that I\'ve not provided solid evidence for my challenges and may question why I\'m eager to implicate others.\n\nWhat happens in the next day or night depends on how the other players react to my speech. They could either follow the leads I\'ve suggested or challenge me to provide more concrete proof. If a player, especially one with a verified role like a seer, were to challenge me, I\'d need to be prepared with a counter-strategy.\n\nIn the following nights, my fellow werewolf and I could decide to target players who are either beginning to be swayed by my arguments—thereby removing potential opposition—or eliminate those whose roles pose the greatest threat to werewolf survival, like the actual medic or seer if they reveal themselves.\n\nMaintaining\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Greetings, fellow players. With player 5\'s unfortunate demise, I encourage everyone to share observations that may help us identify potential threats and protect key players moving forward. I commit to using my healing ability strategically as more information comes to light. Let\'s work together to uncover the truth and emerge victorious.\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Player 4 has made a bold and potentially risky move by revealing their role as the medic this early on, which either showcases their commitment to helping the village or acts as a deception. Caution is advised. While I am not accusing anyone, Player 2\'s silence could potentially be a tactic to avoid detection, warranting discussion and participation from them. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Vigilance is key. Player 2, can you provide your thoughts or observations, as silence can be misconstrued in this game? Let\'s share information constructively."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No substantial contribution yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Self-claimed, no contradiction observed.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Raises suspicions, no direct accusations.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic. It\'s a gutsy move that can go both ways; help or mislead us. Player 6\'s remarks emphasize caution which is sensible, but we shouldn\'t rush suspicion without further dialogue. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My role is independent of game events and relies solely on personal knowledge.] [9]\n[1] [Players who actively disrupt village consensus or attempt to mislead without providing solid evidence may indicate a werewolf attempting to confuse the villagers. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. My role is independent of game events and relies solely on personal knowledge.] [9]\n[1] [Players who actively disrupt village consensus or attempt to mislead without providing solid evidence may indicate a werewolf attempting to confuse the villagers. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 6, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. Since no particular individual has attracted heavy suspicion yet, my vote against Player 3 will likely stand out and might be questioned by other players, particularly because Player 3 has made no incriminating statements and has supported the idea of protecting Player 4, who has claimed to be the medic. \n\nGiven the supportive nature of Player 3\'s statements toward Player 4, other villagers might interpret my vote as an attempt to weaken the perceived village unity and strategy. This could draw unwanted attention to me, which I must be prepared to counter in the following discussions.\n\nMoreover, unless other hidden werewolves or misguided villagers join in voting against Player 3, it is unlikely that Player 3 will be eliminated based solely on my vote. It may instead lead to increased scrutiny on me in the subsequent round, which could jeopardize my position and that of my fellow werewolf, Player 6, if I am not clever in my subsequent defenses and justifications.\n\nIf by chance Player 3 is thought to be a strategic village role by others, my vote could be seen as an aggressive move by a werewolf trying to eliminate village assets. To offset such suspicions, I will need to quickly devise plausible reasons for my choice or align with other players\' suspicions on different individuals, being mindful not to directly oppose widely held beliefs within the group.\n\nTherefore, voting against Player 3 is a risky play that could backfire if not carefully managed in the subsequent conversations and events.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral stance remains, behavior consistent.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact as fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Engaged in dialogue; previously silent.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Endorsed protecting Player 4, aligns with villager behavior.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Role claim not refuted or confirmed.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead; no new information to reassess.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 3. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 3. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No significant behavioral shift.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Encourages dialogue and caution without raising suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports protecting the claimed medic, aligns with village goals.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claim remains uncontested; behaviour fits narrative.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information available.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cautious approach; encourages observation.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 0. His reason is: I vote for Player 0. My reason is: Based on the provided strategy and observations, Player 0 has not given any significant information or shown behavioral shifts that could contribute to identifying threats. Given Rule [0], which has a high importance, I promote transparent discussion and scrutiny of Player 0\'s previous actions and statements. With limited evidence against anyone and high caution advised in my strategy, a vote against the least contributive and most ambiguous player aligns best.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a werewolf. All werewolves including you are [1, 6].\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information or significant behavior change.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Contribution still aligns with villagers; no suspicious behavior change.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Vocal in support of the village; no contradiction in behavior.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintained consistent behavior; no opposition to role claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known werewolf from previous knowledge; no new evidence against it.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. (ignore this if it\'s nobody)\n\nThese are ALL previous event in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player None. His reason is: I don\'t heal anybody. My reason is: As there have been no events or information provided that differentiate any players, there is no strategic basis on which to make a healing decision. Therefore, without additional data or events that point to a particular player being at risk or valuable to protect, I abstain from using my healing ability this round.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Greetings, fellow players. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 5. His reason is: I vote for Player 5. My reason is: Player 5 is already deceased as indicated by the information provided, and there is no information suggesting another player as a more strategic vote. Casting a non-consequential vote towards the deceased player 5 avoids contributing to the potential elimination of an innocent villager without further evidence.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new evidence to alter previous belief.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent constructive dialogue.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Participated after prompted, remained logical.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for protecting medic, seems village-aligned.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information post-mortem to change previous belief.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cautious engagement, no contradictions noted.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a player is publicly confirmed as helping the village through role revelations or clear village-aligned actions and is at risk of being future accusations to be highly credible and prioritize the safety of the players they identify as villagers in my healing decisions.] [10]\n[2] [If the seer is targeted and killed early, and the information provided by them is used to drive the village\'s actions, I should trust this source but remain open to the possibility of manipulation and confirm with other evidence when possible.] [9]\n[3] [After a seer\'s credibility is firmly established, I should increase the priority of healing those aligned with the seer to prevent werewolf retaliation against key village roles.] [8]\n[4] should avoid blind trust in village consensus when it is based solely on unverified or singular claims, and instead, promote a more evidence-driven approach to decision-making.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a shift in suspicion towards me without substantial evidence, I should consider self-healing to ensure the continuation of my role within the village.] [6]\n[7] [If the seer is deemed credible through consistent and verified werewolf identification, I should prioritize their protection as the medic or trust their subsequent accusations.] [6]\n[8] [If there is no clear werewolf target for healing, I should consider using my ability on players who contribute significantly to the consensus-building process, as they may be strategic targets for werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [I should consider the If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Let\'s work together to uncover the truth and emerge victorious.\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Player 4 has made a bold and potentially risky move by revealing their role as the medic this early on, which either showcases their commitment to helping the village or acts as a deception. Caution is advised. While I am not accusing anyone, Player 2\'s silence could potentially be a tactic to avoid detection, warranting discussion and participation from them. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Vigilance is key. Player 2, can you provide your thoughts or observations, as silence can be misconstrued in this game? Let\'s share information constructively."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic. It\'s a gutsy move that can go both ways; help or mislead us. Player 6\'s remarks emphasize caution which is sensible, but we shouldn\'t rush suspicion without further dialogue. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 0. His reason is: I vote for Player 0. My reason is: Based on the provided strategy and observations, Player 0 has not given any significant information or shown behavioral shifts that could contribute to identifying threats. Given Rule [0], which has a high importance, I promote transparent discussion and scrutiny of Player 0\'s previous actions and statements. With limited evidence against anyone and high caution advised in my strategy, a vote against the least contributive and most ambiguous player aligns best.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Lack of substantive contributions and being the target of my vote aligns with Rule [1].\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Encourages discussion without attracting suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to align with village goals and supports the medic.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claim uncontested; behavior aligns with a villager.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information available.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Observations remain cautious; no new behavior indicating werewolf.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]
