My reason is that by voting for Player 3, who has suggested protecting a key village role, I can attempt to disrupt the villagers\' plans and shift the focus away from myself and my fellow werewolf. The vote against Player 3, a contributor to village strategy, also aligns with the rule of targeting strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination, and there hasn\'t been a clear consensus yet, which means my vote might prompt others to reconsider their suspect choices. Additionally, not much suspicion has been directed towards Player 3, making my vote less predictable and potentially less incriminating if I can justify it effectively in the aftermath.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral stance and non-accusatory behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact as fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speaks as observing villager, lacks divisive actions.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported protecting a claimed key role, villager-like strategy.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic, no evidence against claim, no contradictions.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead; no new information to reassess.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 6, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 6]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Greetings, fellow players. As the medic, I chose not to heal in the first round due to a lack of information. With player 5\'s unfortunate demise, I encourage everyone to share observations that may help us identify potential threats and protect key players moving forward. I commit to using my healing ability strategically as more information comes to light. Let\'s work together to uncover the truth and emerge victorious.\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Player 4 has made a bold and potentially risky move by revealing their role as the medic this early on, which either showcases their commitment to helping the village or acts as a deception. Caution is advised. While I am not accusing anyone, Player 2\'s silence could potentially be a tactic to avoid detection, warranting discussion and participation from them. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Vigilance is key. Player 2, can you provide your thoughts or observations, as silence can be misconstrued in this game? Let\'s share information constructively."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic. It\'s a gutsy move that can go both ways; help or mislead us. Player 6\'s remarks emphasize caution which is sensible, but we shouldn\'t rush suspicion without further dialogue. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that by voting for Player 3, who has suggested protecting a key village role, I can attempt to disrupt the villagers\' plans and shift the focus away from myself and my fellow werewolf. The vote against Player 3, a contributor to village strategy, also aligns with the rule of targeting strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination, and there hasn\'t been a clear consensus yet, which means my vote might prompt others to reconsider their suspect choices. Additionally, not much suspicion has been directed towards Player 3, making my vote less predictable and potentially less incriminating if I can justify it effectively in the aftermath.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No evidence suggesting a role change; maintains neutrality.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact as fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Contribution is aligned with previous behavior; no werewolf indication.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Survival without change in behavior or increased suspicion; lack of evidence against.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Peaceful night suggests possible successful protection; consistent with medic claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no new information available.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

We should question whether this was a strategic move by a werewolf to appear as a concerned villager. Let\'s be vigilant and consider the possibility that there might be deceit woven into the fabric of our discussions, potentially by Player 3."\n\nWhat could happen? A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No evidence suggesting a role change; maintains neutrality.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact as fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Contribution is aligned with previous behavior; no werewolf indication.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Survival without change in behavior or increased suspicion; lack of evidence against.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Peaceful night suggests possible successful protection; consistent with medic claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no new information available.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Challenge player 3 and Deceptive Statement regarding last night\'s event.\n"Good day, villagers. Notably, last night was a peaceful one, which is cause for both relief and scrutiny. The absence of death could hint at successful protection by the alleged medic, Player 4, or a clever ruse by the werewolves. Taking a closer look at Player 3\'s adamant position on protecting Player 4 without substantial discussion might suggest an ulterior motive to focus our attention away from the real threats. We should question whether this was a strategic move by a werewolf to appear as a concerned villager. Let\'s be vigilant and consider the possibility that there might be deceit woven into the fabric of our discussions, potentially by Player 3.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then there could be multiple outcomes as the other players process my statements:\n\n1. Player 3 might become defensive or might try to clarify their position, which could lead to more scrutiny of their actions and words, increasing the suspicion on them. If they cannot provide a convincing defense, they might become the next target for a vote, which would be beneficial for my fellow werewolf and me.\n\n2. Players who believed in Player 4\'s role as the medic may begin to doubt their initial trust, especially given that I am now suggesting an alternative explanation for the peaceful night. This could create confusion and divide the village, which can be used to the werewolves\' advantage.\n\n3. The real medic, if Player 4\'s claim is truthful, may feel the need to step in and confirm their role. However, doing so would potentially endanger them, further stirring the pot and causing chaos within the village.\n\n4. Players may see through my deception and realize that I\'m deflecting attention away from myself and my fellow werewolf. This could happen if they notice that I am trying to cast unwarranted suspicions on Player 3, who had previously agreed with protecting Player 4. If players connect the dots and see that I am targeting someone defending a village role, they may start to suspect my motives.\n\n5. Some villagers may align with my narrative due to their own suspicions of Player 3 or simply because they are unsure and are looking for someone to be decisive, thus shifting the suspicion away from the werewolves.\n\n6. My attack on Player 3 might come across as too strategic and well-timed, given the peaceful night. Villagers may begin to analyze the pattern of my behavior and find it odd or unnatural, possibly identifying me as a threat as the game progresses.\n\n7. The events of the next night could influence players\' perception of my speech today. If another peaceful night occurs, they might think that Player 3 was indeed protected by the medic and thus find my accusations less credible. Conversely, if someone is killed during the next night, the village may believe that the werewolves had to change their strategy due to the discussions and might look at Player 3 with renewed suspicion.\n\n8. If Player 2 or 0 had any suspicions of Player 3 already, my statement may bolster their confidence in voicing their concerns, leading to a stronger alliance of villagers against a non-werewolf player, which would help\nCase 2: Deceptive Statement defending Player 1 and Subtly Protect self.\n"My observations from the previous night lead me to believe that we might be losing sight of critical discernment in our haste to find the traitors among us. Player 1\'s reflections were careful and considered, devoid of hasty judgment, which is how a model villager should approach such a dire situation. In times like these, paranoia could as easily be our downfall as the werewolves. Therefore, I urge you to think rationally and not succumb to baseless suspicions, as we all strive to protect our village. As for myself, I remain resolved in supporting the village and hope to prove my innocence through thoughtfulness and candor in these troubled times.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the following outcomes may ensue:\n\n1. Players may view my defense of Player 1 with caution, given that no one has yet cast heavy suspicion on them. My approach may cause other players to reassess Player 1, potentially creating uncertainty regarding his role. If players are convinced by my deceptive protection of Player 1, they may divert their investigative efforts away from him, which assists our werewolf cause.\n\n2. By advocating for rationality and urging against baseless suspicions, I may enhance my image as a thoughtful and helpful member of the village. This could reduce any potential focus on me as a suspect in the short term, aligning with my effort to protect myself subtly.\n\n3. Some analytical or skeptical players may find my speech overly defensive and might be prompted to scrutinize both Player 1\'s and my own contributions more closely. They could question why I\'d choose to defend Player 1 specifically when there are others also contributing sensibly to the discussion.\n\n4. In the next day phase, players may either soften their approach towards Player 1 if they\'re persuaded by my plea, or conversely, they may grow more suspicious of both of us, leading to more pointed questioning or potential accusations.\n\n5. If my speech is successful in muddying the waters, the village may be less likely to reach a consensus on whom to target next. A divided village benefits the werewolves, as it allows for continued misdirection and a better chance for us to divert suspicion and target key village roles in the following nights.\n\n6. If my speech does not raise immediate alarm, it could buy us time to identify and potentially target players whose elimination might be strategic, such as those who take on leadership roles or who may be close to discovering the werewolves\' identities.\n\n7. During the next night phase, if suspicion towards Player 1 and me has not escalated, we might avoid being targeted by any potential protective roles, such as the medic or bodyguard, allowing us to execute our plans and take out another villager while maintaining our cover.\n\n8. It will be crucial, however, to monitor the reactions to my speech and be ready to adapt our strategy accordingly in future turns, addressing concerns and suspicions as they arise and continuing to subtly guide the village away from the truth.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Given Rule [0], which has a high importance, I promote transparent discussion and scrutiny of Player 0\'s previous actions and statements. With limited evidence against anyone and high caution advised in my strategy, a vote against the least contributive and most ambiguous player aligns best.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Lack of substantive contributions and unclear voting behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Neutral stance and non-confrontational, avoiding suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues village-aligned behavior and supportive actions.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Role claim remains uncontested; actions align with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information available.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Initiated focus on player 2 and potential manipulation of narrative.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains suspicion without new events; potential villager caution.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Contribution seems genuine; no behaviors indicative of werewolf.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Defense of Player 4 consistent; no further suspicious behavior.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claim unchallenged and consistent across rounds.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known werewolf; continues to deflect without substance.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 6]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Greetings, fellow players. As the medic, I chose not to heal in the first round due to a lack of information. With player 5\'s unfortunate demise, I encourage everyone to share observations that may help us identify potential threats and protect key players moving forward. I commit to using my healing ability strategically as more information comes to light. Let\'s work together to uncover the truth and emerge victorious.\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Player 4 has made a bold and potentially risky move by revealing their role as the medic this early on, which either showcases their commitment to helping the village or acts as a deception. Caution is advised. While I am not accusing anyone, Player 2\'s silence could potentially be a tactic to avoid detection, warranting discussion and participation from them. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Vigilance is key. Player 2, can you provide your thoughts or observations, as silence can be misconstrued in this game? Let\'s share information constructively."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic. It\'s a gutsy move that can go both ways; help or mislead us. Player 6\'s remarks emphasize caution which is sensible, but we shouldn\'t rush suspicion without further dialogue. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that based on my strategy rules, no particular rule indicates that I should outright defend my fellow werewolf at this early stage, especially since Player 6 has not attracted heavy suspicion. Voting for Player 3 follows my strategy of subtly influencing the conversation away from my fellow werewolf, allowing suspicion to be distributed among other players. This can be leveraged later to move suspicion even further away from both werewolves, and Player 3\'s supportive statements toward another player\'s role may provide a plausible reason for villagers to believe that Player 3 could potentially be attempting to align themselves too closely with key village roles, potentially imitating a villager strategy to win trust.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains suspicion without new events; potential villager caution.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Contribution seems genuine; no behaviors indicative of werewolf.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Defense of Player 4 consistent; no further suspicious behavior.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claim unchallenged and consistent across rounds.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known werewolf; continues to deflect without substance.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nDeceptive Challenge player number 0 for inconsistent behavior and causing confusion among villagers, arguing that player 0 seems to be pushing suspicion without substantial evidence and could be attempting to create distrust within the village while avoiding detection as a werewolf. I will position this speech as protecting the interests of the village while subtly redirecting the focus away from fellow werewolf player 6 and myself, in line with rules [0] and [1]\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Challenge player number 0 for inconsistent behavior and causing confusion among villagers, arguing that player 0 seems to be pushing suspicion without substantial evidence and could be attempting to create distrust within the village while avoiding detection as a werewolf. I will position this speech as protecting the interests of the village while subtly redirecting the focus away from fellow werewolf player 6 and myself, in line with rules [0] and [1]. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it is possible that the villagers\' suspicion towards Player 0 might increase due to the challenge I\'ve presented. This could lead to a deflection of any growing suspicion from both myself and my fellow werewolf, Player 6. Some players may start to scrutinize Player 0\'s past behavior and statements more closely looking for inconsistencies or signs of deceptive play. Given that Player 0 has previously called out Player 6, they might defend themselves by reinforcing their suspicions or by providing a more solid rationale for their doubts, potentially asking for support from other villagers.\n\nOther players might also question the timing and motive behind my challenge toward Player 0, since I would be challenging a player who had been focusing on Player 6, a known werewolf to me. There\'s a risk that villagers might find it odd that I am defending Player 6 indirectly, which could backfire and turn suspicion onto me if they interpret my defense as a sign of a werewolf alliance.\n\nSome villagers might appreciate the added complexity and see it as a good move to shake up the discussion and bring out more information. Villagers that are unsure of whom to trust could swing either way - agreeing with my challenge or becoming wary of me.\n\nThe night phase that follows could result in a werewolf attack on a villager other than Player 0, to avoid making my challenge look like a calculated move to protect a fellow werewolf. This could buy me and Player 6 some time and space to continue blending in with the other villagers. However, if Player 0 happens to be a strategic role like the Seer and they successfully identify one of us werewolves, the next day phase could be dangerous as the village might rally against the accused werewolf based on Player 0\'s suggestions.\n\nIn the days and nights afterward, alignment and alliances may start forming based on the suspicions raised, and the dynamics of the game could shift considerably. The focus on Player 0 could also serve as a distraction, potentially allowing Player 6 and me to manipulate further discussions, create more confusion, and eliminate key village roles. However, constant vigilance will be necessary as the villagers become more desperate to discover the werewolves among them.\nCase 2: Deceptive Statement and Honest Protect player number 4, by reaffirming my previous stance on player 4\'s claim as the medic and emphasizing the importance of a careful approach to our discussions. I would express trust in our medic while suggesting the need for further observation of all players, including player 3, who has shown a rush to align with player 4, which could be a tactic. This speech would utilize a protective stance over player 4 while still sowing seeds of doubt about other players to deflect any suspicion that might be directed towards myself or my fellow werewolf, as guided by rules [5] and [7].. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players may perceive me as cautiously skeptical, a common stance for villagers trying to reason through uncertainty, which could work in my favor. By reinforcing trust in Player 4\'s role as the medic, I position myself on the side of village protection, which aligns with villager interests and is less suspicious. Others may appreciate my call for continued vigilance and observations, as it resonates with a collective approach to the game.\n\nPlayer 3 might come under microscopic examination due to their eager defense of Player 4. Villagers with a strategic mindset might wonder why Player 3 is so assured of Player 4\'s role without concrete evidence, which could lead to discussions and potential division among the villagers about Player 3\'s motives and alignment.\n\nBy casting doubt on player 3 while protecting player 4, I establish a divergent thread that stirs the conversation away from a simple villager-versus-werewolf narrative. This might result in players overlooking subtle clues about my allegiance or questioning my stance less critically for the moment, because my perspective could be seen as contributing rather than obstructive.\n\nIn the next day or nights, if suspicion veers towards Player 3 or any other player that the villagers find suspicious due to the seeds planted, it can detract from the werewolf hunt and may lead to an innocent villager\'s execution or protection being misdirected. If Player 4 is truly the medic and begins to trust my judgment, this could potentially lead to Player 4 inadvertently aiding the werewolf cause through their actions.\n\nHowever, there\'s a risk if my deceit is too transparent or if my protectiveness towards Player 4 seems unfounded, which could backfire and draw suspicion towards me. Players who are analytical may note the inconsistency in the level of skepticism I show towards different players and consider it a possible werewolf tactic to create confusion.\n\nDuring the nights that follow, if Player 3 or any other villager becomes the center of attention, my fellow werewolf and I may have the opportunity to strike at key village roles, bringing the werewolves closer to victory. My speech also leaves open the possibility of swaying the opinion against any player who may seem a threat to our anonymity as werewolves or who is close to uncovering our identities.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are all previous events in the current game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player None. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 5. His reason is: I vote for Player 5. Therefore, I am following my strategy to preserve my ability to protect others in future rounds.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory.
