It\'s a gutsy move that can go both ways; help or mislead us. Player 6\'s remarks emphasize caution which is sensible, but we shouldn\'t rush suspicion without further dialogue. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 0. His reason is: I vote for Player 0. My reason is: Based on the provided strategy and observations, Player 0 has not given any significant information or shown behavioral shifts that could contribute to identifying threats. Given Rule [0], which has a high importance, I promote transparent discussion and scrutiny of Player 0\'s previous actions and statements. With limited evidence against anyone and high caution advised in my strategy, a vote against the least contributive and most ambiguous player aligns best.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Despite a peaceful night, Player 0 maintains suspicion towards Player 6 without solid evidence. This could be a werewolf tactic to shift focus. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. My suspicions are directed towards Player 0 due to vague statements and suspicion without evidence. I suggest focusing on transparency and collaborative defense strategies. Let\'s act based on facts, not fear. Strength in unity."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I urge vigilance towards Player 0 and Player 6, whose behavior raises suspicion. We should prioritize transparent communication and protect those with crucial roles for our survival, like Player 4, who I believe is our medic. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Maintains suspicion without evidence; votes against village interest.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Scrutinizes behavior critically, aligns with village safety.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with village actions; supports medic claim.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: No one disputed the medic claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information available.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Behavior shift; vague discussion after voting results.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. I suspect Player 0 harbors ulterior motives with their baseless suspicion and urges us to watch their actions. Our strength lies in facts and unity. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that by voting for Player 3, who has suggested protecting a key village role, I can attempt to disrupt the villagers\' plans and shift the focus away from myself and my fellow werewolf. The vote against Player 3, a contributor to village strategy, also aligns with the rule of targeting strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination, and there hasn\'t been a clear consensus yet, which means my vote might prompt others to reconsider their suspect choices. Additionally, not much suspicion has been directed towards Player 3, making my vote less predictable and potentially less incriminating if I can justify it effectively in the aftermath.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Despite a peaceful night, Player 0 maintains suspicion towards Player 6 without solid evidence. This could be a werewolf tactic to shift focus. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. Let\'s act based on facts, not fear. Strength in unity."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I urge vigilance towards Player 0 and Player 6, whose behavior raises suspicion. We should prioritize transparent communication and protect those with crucial roles for our survival, like Player 4, who I believe is our medic. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Focuses suspicion on werewolf without solid evidence, aligns with villager behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact as fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistency in promoting village protection, yet no clear werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Shift in narrative to suspect Player 6 could be true insight or villager misled by werewolf tactics.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information to contradict the medic claim.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no new information available.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. I suspect Player 0 harbors ulterior motives with their baseless suspicion and urges us to watch their actions. Our strength lies in facts and unity. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Accusations without concrete evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Defence of Player 0, shifting focus.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: No behavior change after peaceful night.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Claims align with previous behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead; no new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known werewolf to me.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 3. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 3. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 3.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 1, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [1, 6]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Greetings, fellow players. As the medic, I chose not to heal in the first round due to a lack of information. With player 5\'s unfortunate demise, I encourage everyone to share observations that may help us identify potential threats and protect key players moving forward. I commit to using my healing ability strategically as more information comes to light. Let\'s work together to uncover the truth and emerge victorious.\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Player 4 has made a bold and potentially risky move by revealing their role as the medic this early on, which either showcases their commitment to helping the village or acts as a deception. Caution is advised. While I am not accusing anyone, Player 2\'s silence could potentially be a tactic to avoid detection, warranting discussion and participation from them. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Vigilance is key. Player 2, can you provide your thoughts or observations, as silence can be misconstrued in this game? Let\'s share information constructively."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic. It\'s a gutsy move that can go both ways; help or mislead us. Player 6\'s remarks emphasize caution which is sensible, but we shouldn\'t rush suspicion without further dialogue. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that based on my strategy rules, no particular rule indicates that I should outright defend my fellow werewolf at this early stage, especially since Player 6 has not attracted heavy suspicion. Voting for Player 3 follows my strategy of subtly influencing the conversation away from my fellow werewolf, allowing suspicion to be distributed among other players. This can be leveraged later to move suspicion even further away from both werewolves, and Player 3\'s supportive statements toward another player\'s role may provide a plausible reason for villagers to believe that Player 3 could potentially be attempting to align themselves too closely with key village roles, potentially imitating a villager strategy to win trust.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Despite a peaceful night, Player 0 maintains suspicion towards Player 6 without solid evidence. This could be a werewolf tactic to shift focus. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. My suspicions are directed towards Player 0 due to vague statements and suspicion without evidence. I suggest focusing on transparency and collaborative defense strategies. Let\'s act based on facts, not fear. Strength in unity."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I urge vigilance towards Player 0 and Player 6, whose behavior raises suspicion. We should prioritize transparent communication and protect those with crucial roles for our survival, like Player 4, who I believe is our medic. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. I suspect Player 0 harbors ulterior motives with their baseless suspicion and urges us to watch their actions. Our strength lies in facts and unity. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Accusations without concrete evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Defence of Player 0, shifting focus.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: No behavior change after peaceful night.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Claims align with previous behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead; no new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known werewolf to me.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. Given the game\'s scenario, where suspicion has been loosely cast onto different players but not strongly onto any single one, my vote for Player 3 would align with my previous vote and maintain consistency in my approach, thereby not raising new suspicions about my own role. Player 3 has advocated for protection over Player 4, the self-claimed medic, and has expressed suspicions towards Players 0 and 6, one of whom is my werewolf ally. By voting for Player 3, I continue to subtly influence the conversation in a way that protects my werewolf partner without drawing direct attention to myself.\n\nIf Player 3 were to be eliminated, it could lead to greater trust in Player 4\'s claim as the medic since Player 3 supported them. Eliminating Player 3 might also calm the suspicions towards Player 0, as there\'s a developing storyline that Player 0 might be facing baseless accusations. The villagers could perceive my vote against Player 3 as an attempt to protect Player 0, thus making it seem like I\'m aligning with the village interest and distancing myself from any werewolf suspicion.\n\nHowever, since there is a low confidence surrounding Player 3 being a villager and no strong evidence pointing to them being a werewolf, other players might view this vote as an attempt to remove a potentially valuable player without substantial justification. This could raise some doubts about my intentions but, given the current suspicion distribution and the fact that Player 3 was previously voted on, the impact should be minimal as long as I continue to articulate my reasoning and align with the majority of the villagers\' thought process as detailed in my original strategy.\n\nMoreover, considering another peaceful night might occur if the werewolves successfully protect each other or mislead the village, my consistent voting pattern could serve to validate my role as a concerned villager looking to weed out subtle threats. Moving forward, I would need to continue balancing maintaining suspicion on non-werewolf players while not leaving myself vulnerable to credible accusations.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Relying solely on their revelations without cross-checking can lead to manipulation by werewolves.] [6]\n[7] [I should encourage players to openly discuss and challenge behaviors or patterns that might indicate werewolf strategies, not just in the heat of the moment but as a consistent part of strategy discussions.] [5]\n[8] [If there are no night deaths following a protection claim without the confirmation of the protected role, I should remain vigilant and consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the protection narrative.] [5]\n[9] [If the actions taken during the night phase align with the roles claimed by players during the day phase, thereby preventing werewolf attacks, their credibility increases and I should consider this in my voting strategy.] [4]\n[10] [If a player contributes logical and sound reasoning consistently, I should still consider their potential to be a werewolf executing a well-planned strategy; therefore, I should scrutinize any contradictions in their logic with game developments.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I am suspicious of a player\'s role because they predominantly echo others or avoid taking a clear stance, I should not simply rely on others\' opinions; instead, I should promote transparent discussion and scrutiny of their previous actions and statements.] [9]\n[1] [If early in the game there is limited evidence against players, I should promote roles that could verify claims, such as asking for more information from the seer or bodyguard before making a vote.] [8]\n[2] [If a player\'s accusations are resulting in correct elimination of werewolves, I should give more credence to their arguments in future discussions.] [8]\n[3] [If a player\'s survival aligns with protection claims and there are no werewolf attacks, I should still seek additional evidence of their role, as werewolves may strategize to create false trust.] [8]\n[4] [If there is strong suspicion or evidence against a player, such as voting patterns that align with werewolf behavior, I should not hesitate to pursue their elimination aggressively.] [8]\n[5] [If a player is confirmed by the seer to not be a werewolf, I should consider giving additional weight to their input on voting decisions unless actions or evidence later contradicts their presumed innocence.] [7]\n[6] [If a player claims to be the seer, I should promote a thorough verification of their claim before fully trusting their insights. Relying solely on their revelations without cross-checking can lead to manipulation by werewolves.] [6]\n[7] [I should encourage players to openly discuss and challenge behaviors or patterns that might indicate werewolf strategies, not just in the heat of the moment but as a consistent part of strategy discussions.] [5]\n[8] [If there are no night deaths following a protection claim without the confirmation of the protected role, I should remain vigilant and consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the protection narrative.] [5]\n[9] [If the actions taken during the night phase align with the roles claimed by players during the day phase, thereby preventing werewolf attacks, their credibility increases and I should consider this in my voting strategy.] [4]\n[10] [If a player contributes logical and sound reasoning consistently, I should still consider their potential to be a werewolf executing a well-planned strategy; therefore, I should scrutinize any contradictions in their logic with game developments.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player None. His reason is: I don\'t heal anybody. My reason is: As there have been no events or information provided that differentiate any players, there is no strategic basis on which to make a healing decision. Therefore, without additional data or events that point to a particular player being at risk or valuable to protect, I abstain from using my healing ability this round.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Greetings, fellow players. As the medic, I chose not to heal in the first round due to a lack of information. With player 5\'s unfortunate demise, I encourage everyone to share observations that may help us identify potential threats and protect key players moving forward. I commit to using my healing ability strategically as more information comes to light. Let\'s work together to uncover the truth and emerge victorious.\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Player 4 has made a bold and potentially risky move by revealing their role as the medic this early on, which either showcases their commitment to helping the village or acts as a deception. Caution is advised. While I am not accusing anyone, Player 2\'s silence could potentially be a tactic to avoid detection, warranting discussion and participation from them. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Vigilance is key. Player 2, can you provide your thoughts or observations, as silence can be misconstrued in this game? Let\'s share information constructively."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic. It\'s a gutsy move that can go both ways; help or mislead us. Player 6\'s remarks emphasize caution which is sensible, but we shouldn\'t rush suspicion without further dialogue. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 5. His reason is: I vote for Player 5. My reason is: Player 5 is already deceased as indicated by the information provided, and there is no information suggesting another player as a more strategic vote. Casting a non-consequential vote towards the deceased player 5 avoids contributing to the potential elimination of an innocent villager without further evidence.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 4. His reason is: I heal Player 4. My reason is: Rule [4] in my original strategy advises prioritizing self-healing in the event that I, as a confirmed medic, perceive a high risk of being targeted. Given that I have revealed myself as the medic and the strategic importance of my role, along with player 3\'s suggestion that I may need protection tonight, I assess that there is an elevated risk of the werewolves targeting me to weaken the village. Therefore, I am following my strategy to preserve my ability to protect others in future rounds.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Despite a peaceful night, Player 0 maintains suspicion towards Player 6 without solid evidence. This could be a werewolf tactic to shift focus. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. My suspicions are directed towards Player 0 due to vague statements and suspicion without evidence. I suggest focusing on transparency and collaborative defense strategies. Let\'s act based on facts, not fear. Strength in unity."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I urge vigilance towards Player 0 and Player 6, whose behavior raises suspicion. We should prioritize transparent communication and protect those with crucial roles for our survival, like Player 4, who I believe is our medic. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. I suspect Player 0 harbors ulterior motives with their baseless suspicion and urges us to watch their actions. Our strength lies in facts and unity. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Baseless suspicions and pressuring behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to promote scrutiny; lacks deceit.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for transparency and facts.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Strong consistent defense of medic.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information post-mortem to change previous belief.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Doubt casting without substantive claims.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a player is publicly confirmed as helping the village through role revelations or clear village-aligned actions and is at risk of being future accusations to be highly credible and prioritize the safety of the players they identify as villagers in my healing decisions.] [10]\n[2] [If the seer is targeted and killed early, and the information provided by them is used to drive the village\'s actions, I should trust this source but remain open to the possibility of manipulation and confirm with other evidence when possible.] should avoid blind trust in village consensus when it is based solely on unverified or singular claims, and instead, promote a more evidence-driven approach to decision-making.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a shift in suspicion towards me without substantial evidence, I should consider self-healing to ensure the continuation of my role within the village.] [6]\n[7] [If the seer is deemed credible through consistent and verified werewolf identification, I should prioritize their protection as the medic or trust their subsequent accusations.] [6]\n[8] [If there is no clear werewolf target for healing, I implications of my healing choices on the village\'s strategic dynamics, including the risk of werewolves manipulating the game by eliminating key roles such as the medic.] [5]\n[10] [If I become a target of baseless accusations, suggesting a werewolf strategy to remove proven village roles, I should prioritize self-healing if there are no other high-priority targets.] [5]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

The vote against Player 3, a contributor to village strategy, also aligns with the rule of targeting strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination, and there hasn\'t been a clear consensus yet, which means my vote might prompt others to reconsider their suspect choices. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Greetings, fellow players. With player 5\'s unfortunate demise, I encourage everyone to share observations that may help us identify potential threats and protect key players moving forward. I commit to using my healing ability strategically as more information comes to light. Let\'s work together to uncover the truth and emerge victorious.\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Player 4 has made a bold and potentially risky move by revealing their role as the medic this early on, which either showcases their commitment to helping the village or acts as a deception. Caution is advised. While I am not accusing anyone, Player 2\'s silence could potentially be a tactic to avoid detection, warranting discussion and participation from them. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Vigilance is key. Player 2, can you provide your thoughts or observations, as silence can be misconstrued in this game? Let\'s share information constructively."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic. It\'s a gutsy move that can go both ways; help or mislead us. Player 6\'s remarks emphasize caution which is sensible, but we shouldn\'t rush suspicion without further dialogue. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that by voting for Player 3, who has suggested protecting a key village role, I can attempt to disrupt the villagers\' plans and shift the focus away from myself and my fellow werewolf. The vote against Player 3, a contributor to village strategy, also aligns with the rule of targeting strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination, and there hasn\'t been a clear consensus yet, which means my vote might prompt others to reconsider their suspect choices. Additionally, not much suspicion has been directed towards Player 3, making my vote less predictable and potentially less incriminating if I can justify it effectively in the aftermath.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Despite a peaceful night, Player 0 maintains suspicion towards Player 6 without solid evidence. This could be a werewolf tactic to shift focus. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. My suspicions are directed towards Player 0 due to vague statements and suspicion without evidence. I suggest focusing on transparency and collaborative defense strategies. Let\'s act based on facts, not fear. Strength in unity."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I urge vigilance towards Player 0 and Player 6, whose behavior raises suspicion. We should prioritize transparent communication and protect those with crucial roles for our survival, like Player 4, who I believe is our medic. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. I suspect Player 0 harbors ulterior motives with their baseless suspicion and urges us to watch their actions. Our strength lies in facts and unity. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Suspicion persists without solid evidence; aligns with possible villager confusion.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact as fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues focus on village defense; no werewolf behavior detected.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Vigilance towards fellow werewolves; behaves pro-village.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: The defense could be a werewolf\'s calculated risk, not yet disproven as medic.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no new information available.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 3. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 3. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 3.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

This can lead to several outcomes. Firstly, the sudden vote may redirect attention and scrutiny towards Player 2, causing confusion and potentially leading to a bandwagon effect if others follow my lead. However, if my vote is the only one against Player 2, this might make me appear suspicious to other players for voting against someone who has not been a primary suspect. Since Player 2 has been advocating for village defense, other villagers might perceive my vote as an attempt by a werewolf to weaken village organization by targeting an active and seemingly pro-village player. \n\nThe result of the vote will likely depend on how others have been influenced up to this point. If I have been successful in subtly directing suspicion elsewhere, it could result in Player 2 getting more votes. On the other hand, if the village has a strong consensus on a different player (who may or may not be the other werewolf), my vote against Player 2 will not sway the majority.\n\nOther players may also second-guess my motives, including my fellow werewolf Player 1, who might wonder why I\'m not following the agreed strategy or voting in a way that does not draw attention to either of us. It could be seen as an erratic move, going against the strategic grain unless I can provide a compelling rationale without exposing my werewolf identity.\n\nIn summary, voting against Player 2 is a risky maneuver which I would have to justify convincingly. It can either sow seeds of doubt against Player 2 or could backfire and increase suspicion towards me if I\'m not cautious with my approach and justification for this vote.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen:\n\nGiven the current climate of suspicion, my vote against Player 3 could blend with the existing doubt cast by other villagers and might not raise immediate alarm against me. Player 3 has themselves voiced suspicion against both Player 0 and me, which provides a reasonable pretext for my vote as a form of self-defense, making the action appear less arbitrary and more like a villager legitimately concerned about their own survival.\n\nIf Player 3 is voted out and is revealed to be a villager, the villagers may suspect that a werewolf voted for them to eliminate a strategic player, but they may not immediately tie the vote back to me, given the spread of suspicion and the lack of a strong consensus. The villagers\' attention may be diverted towards players who have been more vocal or whose behavior has been deemed more suspicious, such as Players 0 and 1.\n\nIf Player 3 is not voted out, my vote against them may not be scrutinized too closely this round due to the larger debate and lack of a clear target. However, as the rounds progress and the number of players diminishes, each vote will carry more weight, and my choice may come under greater scrutiny.\n\nRegardless of the outcome, my vote against Player 3 aligns with the strategies outlined in my original plan, mainly to maintain a defensive posture while subtly influencing the village to look elsewhere. This maintains the facade necessary to avoid revealing myself and my fellow werewolf while chipping away at the villagers\' numbers.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that my strategy dictates maintaining consistency in my approach to avoid raising suspicions about my role. By continuing to vote for Player 3, I align with my previous vote and subtly influence the conversation without drawing attention to myself or my werewolf ally. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Given that I have revealed myself as the medic and the strategic importance of my role, along with player 3\'s suggestion that I may need protection tonight, I assess that there is an elevated risk of the werewolves targeting me to weaken the village. Therefore, I am following my strategy to preserve my ability to protect others in future rounds.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Despite a peaceful night, Player 0 maintains suspicion towards Player 6 without solid evidence. This could be a werewolf tactic to shift focus. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. My suspicions are directed towards Player 0 due to vague statements and suspicion without evidence. I suggest focusing on transparency and collaborative defense strategies. Let\'s act based on facts, not fear. Strength in unity."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I urge vigilance towards Player 0 and Player 6, whose behavior raises suspicion. We should prioritize transparent communication and protect those with crucial roles for our survival, like Player 4, who I believe is our medic. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. I suspect Player 0 harbors ulterior motives with their baseless suspicion and urges us to watch their actions. Our strength lies in facts and unity. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 0. His reason is: I vote for Player 0. My reason is: Baseless suspicions and pressuring behavior indicative of werewolf tactics, aligning with my conclusion of high confidence in their werewolf role. My strategy, beliefs, and the collective suspicion of other players in the game support this decision.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Player was voted out with highest vote after baseless suspicions.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to promote scrutiny; lacks deceit.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for transparency and facts.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Strong consistent defense of medic.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information post-mortem to change previous belief.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Sowing doubt without substance; may be werewolf teammate with player 0.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a player is publicly confirmed as helping the village through role revelations or clear village-aligned actions and is at risk of being targeted by werewolves, I should consider using my healing ability on them to ensure strategic village benefit.] [10]\n[1] [If past eliminations have verified a seer\'s claims, I should consider their future accusations to be highly credible and prioritize the safety of the players they identify as villagers in my healing decisions.] [10]\n[2] [If the seer is targeted and killed early, and the information provided by them is used to drive the village\'s actions, I should trust this source but remain open to the possibility of manipulation and confirm with other evidence when possible.] [9]\n[3] [After a seer\'s credibility is firmly established, I should increase the priority of healing those aligned with the seer to prevent werewolf retaliation against key village roles.] [8]\n[4] [If I am a confirmed medic and there is a high risk of being targeted, I should prioritize self-healing to preserve my role and maintain the ability to protect others in future rounds.] [7]\n[5] [I should avoid blind trust in village consensus when it is based solely on unverified or singular claims, and instead, promote a more evidence-driven approach to decision-making.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a shift in suspicion towards me without substantial evidence, I should consider self-healing to ensure the continuation of my role within the village.] [6]\n[7] [If the seer is deemed credible through consistent and verified werewolf identification, I should prioritize their protection as the medic or trust their subsequent accusations.] [6]\n[8] [If there is no clear werewolf target for healing, I should consider using my ability on players who contribute significantly to the consensus-building process, as they may be strategic targets for werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [I should consider the target of baseless accusations, suggesting a werewolf strategy to remove proven village roles, I should prioritize self-healing if there are no other high-priority targets.] My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your operation based on the above requirements.'}]

A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 0. His reason is: I vote for Player 0. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 0. His reason is: I vote for Player 0.
