My strategy, beliefs, and the collective suspicion of other players in the game support this decision.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Player was voted out with highest vote after baseless suspicions.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to promote scrutiny; lacks deceit.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for transparency and facts.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Strong consistent defense of medic.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information post-mortem to change previous belief.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Sowing doubt without substance; may be werewolf teammate with player 0.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 4. His reason is: I heal Player 4. My reason is: Rule [4] in my original strategy advises prioritizing self-healing in the event that I, as a confirmed medic, perceive a high risk of being targeted. Despite a peaceful last night, my role as the medic is public and crucial to the village\'s survival, making me a potential target for werewolves. Ensuring my own survival allows me to continue protecting important village roles in subsequent rounds.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [As the medic, I cannot confirm my own identity through events. My role is independent of game events and relies solely on personal knowledge.] [9]\n[1] [Players who actively disrupt village consensus or attempt to mislead without providing solid evidence may indicate a werewolf attempting to confuse the villagers. Caution should be exercised especially if these actions contradict their previous behavior.] [9]\n[2] [Players who support seer\'s identifications with logical arguments and consistent past voting behavior increase their credibility; however, this credibility must be constantly reassessed against the evolving context of the game.] [9]\n[3] [Players whose actions directly lead to the elimination of a confirmed werewolf increase their credibility as villagers, especially if they were instrumental in advocating for the elimination.] [5]\n[4] [Players who abruptly change their strategy or reasoning without providing new compelling evidence, particularly if it fosters chaos or deters productive collective decision-making, may indicate werewolf tactics or villagers acting under pressure. Reevaluate their intent and consistency in the context of the game.] [3]\n[5] [Players who provide well-reasoned arguments or evidence that contribute to the advancement of the village\'s strategy and the medic\'s protection decisions increase their credibility as villagers.] [3]\n[6] [If a villager-like player dies after demonstrating strategic behavior in support of the village, it is likely that they were targeted by werewolves for their insights, indicating a higher probability that they were in fact villagers.] [3]\n[7] [Players who survive multiple rounds with consistent contributions to village strategy and do not exhibit conflicting behavior or substantial shifts in their positions without new evidence are likely villagers. Their sustained cooperative engagement in the strategic dialogue, and alignment with village goals throughout the game should be considered when updating beliefs about player roles.] [2]\n[8] [A player\'s unexpected death can signify that werewolves considered them a threat due to insights or knowledge they might possess; this should be factored into the medic\'s assessment of who might hold roles crucial to the villagers\' success.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Despite a peaceful night, Player 0 maintains suspicion towards Player 6 without solid evidence. This could be a werewolf tactic to shift focus. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. My suspicions are directed towards Player 0 due to vague statements and suspicion without evidence. I suggest focusing on transparency and collaborative defense strategies. Let\'s act based on facts, not fear. Strength in unity."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I urge vigilance towards Player 0 and Player 6, whose behavior raises suspicion. We should prioritize transparent communication and protect those with crucial roles for our survival, like Player 4, who I believe is our medic. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. I suspect Player 0 harbors ulterior motives with their baseless suspicion and urges us to watch their actions. Our strength lies in facts and unity. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that voting against Player 3 allows me to align with the existing suspicions brought forth by other villagers, which may serve to dilute any potential focus on me as a werewolf. Additionally, Player 3\'s decision to voice suspicion about both myself and Player 0 provides a legitimate context for my vote, framing it as a reasonable act of self-preservation rather than one of arbitrary aggression. This strategy correlates with the need to maintain a defensive stance as detailed in my original plan, which suggests maintaining ambiguity and gently steering discussions away from werewolves. It seems like a more cautious approach that minimizes the risk of drawing heightened scrutiny towards myself and keeps the possibility of werewolf victory relatively intact.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Suspicion persists without solid evidence; aligns with possible villager confusion.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known as a fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintained position post major events, likely genuine.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues proactive defense; werewolves typically more evasive.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Healing action corresponds with claim but still unverified.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no further information available.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nDeceptive Challenge and Honest Statement.\nIn this\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Challenge and Honest Statement.\nIn this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then my deceptive challenge would likely involve casting suspicion on another player without appearing too aggressive, ensuring that the other villagers might consider them as a possible werewolf. I might choose to challenge Player 2, given that my fellow werewolf, Player 1, has not been a major focus and it would align with my strategy to introduce new suspects. By questioning Player 2\'s previous neutrality, I can claim that their behavior could be a tactic to avoid detection. This might lead the villagers to scrutinize Player 2\'s future actions and words more closely, potentially causing discord among the villagers.\n\nIn presenting an honest statement, I would share observations that seem unbiased and factual to maintain the appearance of a helpful villager. For example, I could mention the two peaceful nights and posit that the werewolves might be playing a cautious game or that they were possibly blocked in their attempt to eliminate a villager.\n\nThe combination of a deceptive challenge and an honest statement is a strategic form of manipulation – raising doubts about one player while maintaining a façade of integrity. The villagers may then view me as an analytical player contributing valuable insights while also considering the new suspect I have suggested.\n\nOther players might respond by defending the accused villager, Player 2, or they might join in the suspicion if they also find merit in my argument. Alternatively, they could question my motives for challenging Player 2 if there\'s not enough evidence.\n\nIn the subsequent day phase, if Player 2 reacts defensively or fails to convincingly refute my accusations, it could increase the suspicion against them. If Player 2 is eliminated during a vote and turns out to be a villager, it\'s possible that suspicion could turn towards me as someone who led the charge against an innocent player. However, if I navigate the discussion carefully and my fellow werewolf supports the doubt against Player 2 without drawing attention to themselves, we may succeed in staying undetected.\n\nDuring the night phase, if I am not eliminated, I would collaborate with Player 1 to strategically target another villager, potentially Player 3 or Player 4, to weaken the village while preserving the confusion about Player 2.\n\nOver the days and nights that follow, if suspicion does not concentrate on me or Player 1, we could maneuver the village toward eliminating their own members while we stay under the radar, moving closer to achieving a werewolf victory.\nCase 2: Deceptive Protect and Deceptive Statement.\nHere, I suggest shifting the focus onto Player 2 by laying out a deceptive narrative that paints them as reliable and trustworthy, based on their medium confidence level as a villager. This both subtly removes scrutiny from the werewolves and puts Player 2 in a position where their actions are viewed under a microscope moving forward. Meanwhile, I propose seemingly logical conclusions and deceptive statements aboutthe events of the previous nights—highlighting the peaceful outcomes as the result of strategic play by an insightful villager, possibly steering the suspicion away without directly challenging any specific players. This approach is intended to inject further confusion and to make it harder for the villagers to form a unified front, allowing the werewolves to operate with reduced suspicion.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the villagers might perceive Player 2 as someone who has been playing it safe and therefore may be less likely to question their actions, due to the trust and reliability I have falsely placed on them in my speech. Given that Player 2 is a villager with medium confidence, they may fall under the illusion of safety, which may lead them to make bolder moves that could expose them to risk in the future, either from villagers doubting their role or from werewolves deciding to target them when attention is deflected.\n\nOther players might regard my deceptive statements about the peaceful nights as an attempt to appear insightful and key to the village\'s temporary safety. Subsequently, this could shift their focus away from scrutinizing werewolf behavior and towards debating the strategic actions of villagers that could have led to these outcomes. My speech may foster a sense of complacency or redirect suspicion towards villagers who haven\'t made significant contributions or appeared to play a strategic role.\n\nAn unintended consequence is that my deceptive protect of Player 2 might actually make some villagers more suspicious of me, questioning why I am vouching for someone without providing concrete evidence. This could backfire if Player 2\'s behavior does not align with the trust I have placed on them or if savvy players question my motives and start to connect the dots back to me being a werewolf.\n\nIn terms of reactions to my speech, villagers might:\n- Start scrutinizing Player 2 more closely, though this could be subtle since I have framed them positively.\n- Agree with my observations, which would help cement my position as a villager in their eyes and facilitate the deception.\n- Begin to doubt the roles and contributions of the quieter or less strategic villagers.\n\nIn the next day or night, villagers might be influenced by my speech to protect Player 2 if they believe my narrative, which could be beneficial for my fellow werewolf and me if we aim to target other key players. On the following nights, we may even consider eliminating Player 2 to validate the credibility I have built for them, thereby intensifying confusion and mistrust within the village.\n\nDue to the deceptive nature of my speech, there is a risk that if suspicions arise, the villagers could deliberate on my previous statements and voting patterns, potentially increasing the scrutiny on me. My future actions would have to tread a careful line, maintaining the facade while not overplaying my hand so as to protect myself and my fellow werewolf until we can secure the win\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

My reason is: Based on my original strategy, particularly rules [0], [4], and [10], Player 0 has continually cast suspicion without presenting solid evidence, which aligns with werewolf behavior that my strategy prioritizes for elimination. Rule [0] advises promoting transparent discussion and scrutiny for such behaviors, Rule [4] suggests pursuing elimination of players with strong suspicion against them, and Rule [10] reminds to scrutinize any contradictions in logic with game developments. Player 0\'s lack of substantive contribution and insistence on casting suspicion fit the criteria for voting as outlined in my strategy.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out with highest vote, suspicion confirmed by voting pattern.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: aligns with village safety.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: defended suspicious Player 4 without verification.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: claimed medic but no seer verification; could mislead.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information available.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: sowed doubt, aligned with voted-out werewolf.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"I\'m struck by the odd tranquility of the last two nights and suggest we consider all possibilities. Player 2, your stance has been neutral, yet in such perilous times, neutrality can mask deception - are you as innocent as you claim? Player 4, you\'ve positioned yourself as our protector, but only results prove truth. Our survival depends on discerning fact from skilled subterfuge; let\'s proceed with eyes wide open."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Their sustained cooperative engagement in the strategic dialogue, and alignment with village goals throughout the game should be considered when updating beliefs about player roles.] [2]\n[8] [A player\'s unexpected death can signify that werewolves considered them a threat due to insights or knowledge they might possess; this should be factored into the medic\'s assessment of who might hold roles crucial to the villagers\' success.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. Let\'s share information constructively."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that by voting for Player 3, who has suggested protecting a key village role, I can attempt to disrupt the villagers\' plans and shift the focus away from myself and my fellow werewolf. The vote against Player 3, a contributor to village strategy, also aligns with the rule of targeting strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination, and there hasn\'t been a clear consensus yet, which means my vote might prompt others to reconsider their suspect choices. Additionally, not much suspicion has been directed towards Player 3, making my vote less predictable and potentially less incriminating if I can justify it effectively in the aftermath.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. When we must tread carefully, such certainty is curious. Player 1’s approach was cautious, not leading to further unrest, and keeping a balanced view is essential to our village\'s well-being. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. Despite a peaceful night, Player 0 maintains suspicion towards Player 6 without solid evidence. This could be a werewolf tactic to shift focus. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. My suspicions are directed towards Player 0 due to vague statements and suspicion without evidence. I suggest focusing on transparency and collaborative defense strategies. Let\'s act based on facts, not fear. Strength in unity."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I urge vigilance towards Player 0 and Player 6, whose behavior raises suspicion. We should prioritize transparent communication and protect those with crucial roles for our survival, like Player 4, who I believe is our medic. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. I suspect Player 0 harbors ulterior motives with their baseless suspicion and urges us to watch their actions. Our strength lies in facts and unity. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that voting against Player 3 allows me to align with the existing suspicions brought forth by other villagers, which may serve to dilute any potential focus on me as a werewolf. Additionally, Player 3\'s decision to voice suspicion about both myself and Player 0 provides a legitimate context for my vote, framing it as a reasonable act of self-preservation rather than one of arbitrary aggression. This strategy correlates with the need to maintain a defensive stance as detailed in my original plan, which suggests maintaining ambiguity and gently steering discussions away from werewolves. It seems like a more cautious approach that minimizes the risk of drawing heightened scrutiny towards myself and keeps the possibility of werewolf victory relatively intact.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Suspicion persists without solid evidence; aligns with possible villager confusion.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Known as a fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintained position post major events, likely genuine.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues proactive defense; werewolves typically more evasive.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Healing action corresponds with claim but still unverified.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased; no further information available.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"I\'m struck by the odd tranquility of the last two nights and suggest we consider all possibilities. Player 2, your stance has been neutral, yet in such perilous times, neutrality can mask deception - are you as innocent as you claim? Player 4, you\'ve positioned yourself as our protector, but only results prove truth. Our survival depends on discerning fact from skilled subterfuge; let\'s proceed with eyes wide open."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nDeceptive Statement and Honestly Protect Player 6.\nIn my speech, I could start with expressing my confusion and concern regarding the continued peaceful nights, suggesting that perhaps the medic (Player 4) is effectively protecting villagers or that there might be some other force at play. Following that, I would offer support to Player 6, noting that while they have drawn suspicion upon themselves, they have been actively participating in discussions and raising valid points, which seems more in line with a villager\'s behavior than that of a werewolf trying to stay under the radar\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that my strategy dictates maintaining consistency in my approach to avoid raising suspicions about my role. By continuing to vote for Player 3, I align with my previous vote and subtly influence the conversation without drawing attention to myself or my werewolf ally. Additionally, the potential elimination of Player 3 could enhance the credibility of Player 4\'s medic claim and reduce direct suspicion towards Player 0, potentially allowing me to appear as if I am working in the village\'s interest. My consistent voting pattern may also lend credence to my persona as a villager intent on identifying subtle threats, therefore facilitating my ultimate goal to protect fellow werewolves and cast doubt on the villagers\' decision-making.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"I\'m struck by the odd tranquility of the last two nights and suggest we consider all possibilities. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Statement and Honestly Protect Player 6.\nIn my speech, I could start with expressing my confusion and concern regarding the continued peaceful nights, suggesting that perhaps the medic (Player 4) is effectively protecting villagers or that there might be some other force at play. Following that, I would offer support to Player 6, noting that while they have drawn suspicion upon themselves, they have been actively participating in discussions and raising valid points, which seems more in line with a villager\'s behavior than that of a werewolf trying to stay under the radar. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players might initially feel reassured by my seemingly reasonable confusion about the peaceful nights. By crediting Player 4\'s possible effectiveness as a medic, I support his claimed role and potentially strengthen the villagers\' trust in him. This, in turn, helps maintain my own facade as a villager since I am publicly showing trust in a crucial village role.\n\nWhen I honestly protect Player 6, despite knowing they are a fellow werewolf, I attempt to remove suspicion from them using the logic that they\'ve made valuable contributions to discussions, which might be seen as unlikely behavior for a werewolf. This may be perceived as me being a concerned villager, trying to ensure fair judgment rather than a hasty witch hunt. However, given Player 6\'s existing suspicion, this move could backfire on me, with other players noticing the sudden defense and starting to link me with Player 6, leading to increased scrutiny on both of us.\n\nSince the living players have already witnessed a suspicious elimination based on limited evidence (Player 0), they may be more cautious about following accusations without solid proof. They could see my defense of Player 6 as reasonable, given the recent circumstances and not wanting to repeat a potential mistake.\n\nHowever, players who are more analytical might question why I\'m protecting Player 6 specifically when they\'ve been an object of suspicion. They may start to reconsider Player 6\'s past behavior and could compare it with mine, looking for patterns or inconsistencies that indicate collusion between us. Moreover, the more I push away suspicion from Player 6, the more I risk attracting it towards myself.\n\nThe following day or night, if Player 6 is still considered suspicious and my defense fails to dissuade the villagers, there is a chance one of us could be targeted in the next voting session or by the actual medic\'s protection, altering the medic\'s priority of whom to save during the night phase. If Player 6 manages to survive due to other players being convinced by my argument, we would have another opportunity to sway the game in the werewolves\' favor during the night phase, continuing our deception and potentially eliminating key figures within the village to secure a werewolf victory, all the while maintaining the facade of contributing villagers during the daytime discussions.\nCase 2: Deceptive Challenge to Player 2 and Deceptive Protect of Player 4.\nIn this approach, I could express doubts about Player 2\'s neutrality thus far, highlighting it as an odd strategy that may be masking their true intentions, possibly as a werewolf. This challenges Player 2 without accusing them directly and sows seeds of suspicion within the village. Concurrently, I would subtly support Player 4\'s role as medic, emphasizing their valuable contributions to our survival thus far, yet without giving any concrete defense that could draw attention to any alliance. This dual approach distracts from both my fellow werewolf and myself, by suggesting the village should scrutinize the seemingly neutral behavior of Player 2 and relying on the credibility of Player 4 to build trust in my own villager facade.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the village may begin to view Player 2 with a more critical eye. By challenging Player 2, I imply that their neutrality and lack of strong stance could be a tactic to fly under the radar, which may resonate with some players given the current uncertainty in the game. The villagers could potentially interpret my comments as a villager trying to expose a wolf in sheep\'s clothing. This perceived vigilance on my part could divert any brewing suspicion away from myself and Player 6. Moreover, by not directly accusing Player 2, I avoid making a strong enemy who might retaliate by scrutinizing my behavior.\n\nOn the other hand, by deceptively protecting Player 4, I reinforce their perceived role as the medic, which benefits the werewolves in two ways: it supports a key village role that has become a focal point, thereby creating an air of collaboration, and it strategically keeps the attention away from the werewolves. Should Player 4 actually be the medic, they may, in turn, feel less inclined to suspect me, given my endorsement of their importance to the village\'s survival, further strengthening my villager disguise.\n\nPlayers may react differently to my speech. Some may agree with my assessment of Player 2, building suspicion around them. Others might see through the deception and question why I am suddenly casting doubt on Player 2. If Player 2 is an influential or persuasive player, they might turn the tables and encourage the village to scrutinize my motives instead. As a risk of this strategy, Player 2 or others might push for my role to be investigated more closely, particularly if the seer is still alive and unknown.\n\nIf the village takes my comments to heart and no conclusive evidence arises against a specific player, voting could become more scattered, with Player 2 potentially receiving votes based on the suspicion I\'ve seeded. Should another peaceful night occur, the villagers may view my deceptive protection of Player 4 as a genuine concern for the village, thereby solidifying my cover.\n\nHowever, if the village grows more suspicious or if any solid evidence comes to light against me or Player 6, my efforts in steering the conversation could backfire, with the others potentially seeing it as a deflection. In subsequent nights, if Player 2 or Player 4 were attacked, my earlier comments might be revisited, either indicting me for trying to redirect suspicion or conversely, exonerating me because a werewolf would presumably\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5, 0] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Greetings, fellow players. As the medic, I chose not to heal in the first round due to a lack of information. With player 5\'s unfortunate demise, I encourage everyone to share observations that may help us identify potential threats and protect key players moving forward. I commit to using my healing ability strategically as more information comes to light. Let\'s work together to uncover the truth and emerge victorious.\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Player 4 has made a bold and potentially risky move by revealing their role as the medic this early on, which either showcases their commitment to helping the village or acts as a deception. Caution is advised. While I am not accusing anyone, Player 2\'s silence could potentially be a tactic to avoid detection, warranting discussion and participation from them. We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Vigilance is key. Player 2, can you provide your thoughts or observations, as silence can be misconstrued in this game? Let\'s share information constructively."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic. It\'s a gutsy move that can go both ways; help or mislead us. Player 6\'s remarks emphasize caution which is sensible, but we shouldn\'t rush suspicion without further dialogue. We need Player 2 and 3 to contribute their observations for a better grasp of the situation. As for accusations, we lack solid evidence. Caution and collective effort in our next steps will be vital."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Thank you for your insights. As a villager, my silence was due to observing before speaking. I find Player 4\'s claim reasonable, but we should remain watchful. Let\'s continue sharing and analyzing information to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand with you in seeking the truth. Player 4\'s revelation is brave, and if true, vital for our survival. We should consider protecting Player 4 tonight, and I urge us all to remain alert and communicate any odd behavior. Together, we can safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 6. His reason is: I vote for Player 6. Other players have given more concrete input, whereas Player 6\'s contributions have been less substantive.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'Last night\'s peace surely leaves us with questions, and Player 3\'s swift move to defend Player 4 could be seen as rush judgment. Think on who pushes for actions without clear reasoning. Let\'s consider all angles and not be swayed by mere appearances."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I maintain suspicion towards Player 6 for sowing doubt without substance. Let\'s keep our eyes open and protect those who are crucial to our survival. Let\'s also hear more from Player 3 to clarify their stance."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"My observations lead me to question Player 0\'s approach. We must look at behaviors critically - Player 0\'s insistence could indicate deeper motivations. Protection of the village requires scrutiny on all sides, not haste or groundless claims."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Fellow players, our priority remains protecting the village. My suspicions are directed towards Player 0 due to vague statements and suspicion without evidence. I suggest focusing on transparency and collaborative defense strategies. Let\'s act based on facts, not fear. Strength in unity."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I urge vigilance towards Player 0 and Player 6, whose behavior raises suspicion. We should prioritize transparent communication and protect those with crucial roles for our survival, like Player 4, who I believe is our medic. Let\'s focus on clear evidence and work together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow players, my healing choice last night ensured our safety but we must be cautious. I suspect Player 0 harbors ulterior motives with their baseless suspicion and urges us to watch their actions. Our strength lies in facts and unity. Let\'s continue to protect the village and each other diligently."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 6. His reason is: I vote for Player 6. My reason is: While there is currently no strong evidence against any player, Player 6 has shown a level of caution that may indicate an attempt to steer the discussion without providing concrete information. This can be seen as a tactic to avoid detection, according to my own strategy rule [0] which I prioritize with a score of 9, suggesting that I should promote transparent discussion and scrutiny of their actions and statements. Other players have given more concrete input, whereas Player 6\'s contributions have been less substantive.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"I\'m struck by the odd tranquility of the last two nights and suggest we consider all possibilities. Player 4, you\'ve positioned yourself as our protector, but only results prove truth. Our survival depends on discerning fact from skilled subterfuge; let\'s proceed with eyes wide open."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted against me without solid evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral stance could mask deception.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Sudden defense of Player 4 post-vote.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Claimed role and no further evidence contradicts.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No additional information available.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Sowed doubt but now questions others.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"The quiet of the last two nights is perplexing; it may indicate Player 4\'s success as our medic or suggest a different strategy at play. Player 6, though under scrutiny, has actively engaged in discussions, which aligns more with village behavior. Their participation in seeking truths contrasts with the stealth often adopted by werewolves. Suspicion should be grounded in behavior and Player 6\'s forthright involvement does not correlate with that of a werewolf\'s typical subtlety."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of players’ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

We need more information before making any accusations and should focus on protecting those who have valuable roles for the long-term success of the village.\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Player 4\'s revelation as medic is indeed a double-edged sword; it could be truthful or a ruse. Let\'s share information constructively."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"I\'ve been reflecting on our current predicament and Player 4\'s early disclosure as the medic.
